text:
Wellington Airport's 1959 gala opening a bumpy ride - 150 Years of News MATT STEWART Last updated 05:00, October 19 2015 ALEXANDER TURNBULL LIBRARY PAColl-0785-1-026-14 
Crowds inspect aircraft at the opening of Wellington Airport in 1959, which The Evening Post described as "New Zealand's biggest ever air pageant". 
The unveiling of Wellington's new multimillion-dollar airport in 1959 was almost marred by a fatal air tragedy when a Vulcan bomber clipped the southern end of the airfield. 
Vulcan navigator 88-year-old retired Wing Commander Bryn Lewis recalled the incident in 2013 when he told The Dominion Post he thought he and scores of onlookers would die when the bomber nearly bombed. 
"I thought we were going to die ... and people on the ground were going to die," Lewis said. AIR FORCE MUSEUM 
The RAF Vulcan crash-landed at Ohakea after a near-miss at the opening of Wellington Airport. 
As the huge British Royal Air Force plane spewed fuel, Captain Tony Smailes avoided ploughing into crowds by going full throttle and pulling the plane and its five crew back into the air. They managed a crash-landing at Ohakea. 
"Like a mighty bird alighting, the Vulcan bomber appears to perch on the edge of the Wellington Airport embankment," The Evening Post reported at the time. 
It lost its left rear wheel as its undercarriage and left wingtip hit the ground. 
That wasn't the only close call that day – earlier on October 25 the pilot of a Sunderland flying boat scraped the plane's belly on the runway during his low-level flyover – not knowing the Evans Bay end of the runway was about six metres higher than the Cook Strait end. The plane had to be quickly beached before it sank. 
Ultimately disaster was avoided and thousands turned up amid much fanfare. The occasion followed a month of hype in both the capital's daily newspapers to the great unveiling, which marked the the end of one of New Zealand's largest civil engineering projects. 
Construction began in 1953 and involved 135 acres of land reclamation, extensive road building and shifting of the sewer outfall as well as the relocation of 180 houses. 
In the following six years, more than three million cubic metres of earth and rock was moved, including shifting Rongotai Hill. Houses that weren't demolished were moved to reclaimed land at Evans Bay. Ad Feedback 
The airport cost an inflation-adjusted $216m to build, with Wellington City Council contributed stumping up about a third. 
Lyall Bay had been Wellington's home of flight since Arthur Schaef built an aircraft in 1910, less than a decade after the Wright brothers' first flight, and flew it a few metres along Lyall Bay. 
Sandhills were levelled for flying, then, in 1928, a couple of small runways were built. The next year, Charles Kingsford Smith touched down in Wellington at the end of the first trans-Tasman flight.
